ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TEMPORARY ASSISTANT MARKETS AND HAWKERS
INSPECTORS EMPLOYED BY CITY COUNCIL


    1. Inche Mohd Ali Bin Alwi asked the Prime Minister how many Temporary Assistant Markets and Hawkers Inspectors were employed by the City Council as at 31st August, 1960; how many of them were appointed from among former serving officers of the City Council, and how many passed (a) English Standard Eight, (b) Chinese Junior Middle, (c) Malay Standard Seven, and (d) an equivalent standard in Tamil.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker. I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    There were 25 Temporary Assistant Markets and Hawkers Inspectors employed by the City Council as at 31st August, 1960. None of these were from among former serving officers. Seven have passed English Standard VIII. Four have passed Chinese Junior Middle, and one has passed Malay Standard VII. None has passed the equivalent standard in Tamil. In addition to the above, three possess the Cambridge School Certificate, and nine possess the Chinese Senior Middle Certificate - these being higher qualifications than those referred to by the Member for the Southern Islands.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib: I am the Member for the Southern Islands!

    Mr Speaker: It is the Member for Kampong Kembangan.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the information supplied by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, does it mean that the serving officers in the City Council have no qualifications to enable them to carry out these duties?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: I do not understand the question.

Column: 615



    Mr Speaker: Will the Member for Kampong Kembangan repeat the question slowly?

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, is it true that the officers serving in these posts in the City Council were not eligible?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: No. None were selected although many of them applied.

    Inche Mohd. Ali(In Malay): Is it because those serving officers in the City Council who applied did not possess the qualifications?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: Mr Speaker, Sir, further notice of that question is required.

CITY COUNCIL TRANSPORT AND
RURAL BOARD CLEANSING DEPARTMENTS
(Disciplinary action against drivers)


    2. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Prime Minister (a) whether he personally took action to sack a driver of the City Council Transport Department in March 1960, and on what grounds; and whether the Rules of the City Council were followed in this case; (b) whether he personally directed that disciplinary action be taken against a driver of the Rural Board Cleansing Department who was driving a Cleansing Department lorry along East Coast Road on Vesak Day, and on what grounds; and (c) on how many occasions has he initiated disciplinary action against labourers under his jurisdiction.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    (a) The driver was specially employed by the ex-Minister for National Development for the Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of National Development. The Parliamentary Secretary found the driver unsatisfactory and he was given one month's notice of termination of service in March.

    (b) The Prime Minister reported the crew of a lorry of the Rural Board Cleansing Section for disciplinary action for reckless speeding and allowing refuse from their lorry to fall and litter

Column: 616

Bedok Road. They were disciplined after due enquiry and received no pay that day. The driver and co-driver concerned were transferred to another section.

    (c) The Prime Minister's report initiated disciplinary action in this instance.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware of any rules in the City Council whereby labourers are engaged for specific jobs, or has there been any labourer engaged by the City Council on specific jobs?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: The driver was specially employed by the ex-Minister for National Development on a temporary basis. Therefore, it has nothing to do with the rules of the City Council.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the Prime Minister initiated disciplinary action against the second driver in question because he did not recognise the Prime Minister?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: It is not a question of whether he recognised the Prime Minister or not. It concerns the attitude of a civil servant towards a member of the public.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware, on (c), that the Prime Minister had either taken disciplinary action against or picked quarrels with almost all the labourers in Changi bungalow?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: I am not aware of that.

GOVERNMENT AND OFFICIAL CARS USED BY PRIME MINISTER,
MINISTERS AND PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARIES
(Statistics)


    3. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Prime Minister (a) what is the total number of Government and official cars being used by the Prime Minister, Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries; (b) to give details of the cost per month in respect of (i) wages and overtime pay, provident fund contributions and quarters for chauffeurs; (ii) road tax; (iii) petrol and lubricants; (iv) maintenance, such as repairs, replacement of tyres, etc.; and (v)

Column: 617

estimated depreciation, or loss of income from hire; and (c) to give the following details of each car:- (i) registration number; (ii) by whom is the car used; (iii) model; and (iv) whether any chauffeur is provided.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question:

    (a) Ministers, when travelling on official duty, use cars from the Government pool which consists of: 

         3 State cars (including the former Mayor's car);

         1 official car.


    Parliamentary Secretaries use Government transport only on ceremonial occasions.

    (b) (i) Wages for chauffeurs - 
  

         $468.75 per month for three drivers.

         

         Overtime pay -

             $12 per month (average).

             

         Provident Fund -

             $23.43 per month for three drivers.

             

         Quarters for drivers -

             No free quarters are provided.


    (b) (ii) Road tax - 
  

         $28 per month for three cars.


    (b) (iii) Petrol and lubricants - 

         $259.85 per month for three cars (average).


    (b) (iv) Maintenance such as repairs, etc - 
  

         $155.82 for the three cars (average).

         

         Payment to City Council for use of former Mayor's car -

             $240 per month (average).


    (b) (v) Nil.

    (c) (i) The registration numbers of the cars are S1, S3 and SR2.

    (c) (ii) S3 and SR2 are normally used by the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister respectively. All cars are used by Ministers and visiting dignitaries.

    (c) (iii) S1 - 8-year old Humber Pull-man 1952 model.

    S3 - 5-year old Super Snipe 1955 model.

    SR2 - 5-year old Humber Hawk 1955 model.

    (c) (iv) The cars are looked after and driven by syces.

    Mr S. V. Lingam: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the Ministers and Assistant Ministers of the previous Government did not use official cars?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: We are not responsible for the previous Government.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, could the Parliamentary Secretary give us the number of cars that are being reserved for the use of Parliamentary Secretaries on so-called "ceremonial occasions"?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: No, it is not true.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, I want the number: either yes or no, or one or five?

    Mr Speaker: Could the hon. Member repeat the question?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, could the Parliamentary Secretary give us the figure of transport used by Parliamentary Secretaries on only so-called ceremonial occasions?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: None.

"SRI TEMASEK"
(Costs of decoration and upkeep)


    4. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Prime Minister (a) what was the total cost, giving breakdown details, of the decoration in May, 1960, of "Sri Temasek";

Column: 619

(b) what was the purpose of beautifying and air-conditioning one of the bedrooms, and for whom; and (c) what is the monthly total cost, giving breakdown details, in the upkeep of "Sri Temasek".

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply to this question.

    The total cost of decorating "Sri Temasek" in May 1960 was $194. These decorations were carried out in connection with National Day. In addition, a sum of $29,790 was spent on painting and structural works and repairs, and air-conditioning the lounge.

    One air-conditioned bedroom was prepared for the use of State guests. The cost is 2,681.

    The total cost of decorating "Sri Temasek" is $172.50 per month for one houseboy, $14.53 for a telephone per month, and $240 per month for water and light.

    Mr A. P. Rajah: Could the Parliamentary Secretary tell the House whether these items of expenditure are covered by budgetary provisions?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: Further notice of that question is required.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that there might be other expenses covered by other votes which are not included?

    Mr Speaker: Does the Parliamentary Secretary wish to answer that question? It appears to be hypothetical.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: Mr Speaker, I consider the question to be irrelevant.

    Mr Speaker: The Parliamentary Secretary must depend on the Chair to decide whether a question is irrelevant or not.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, can the Parliamentary Secretary tell me why only one room is air-conditioned and not all the rooms, if they are meant for guests?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: We do not have many State guests visiting us often.

    Mr Rajah: Could a Member of this Assembly use that room?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: No, he cannot.

    Mr Rajah: Could a Minister of this Assembly use that room?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: No.

GOLF-LINKS IN ISTANA NEGARA GROUNDS


    5. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Prime Minister (a) what is the total monthly cost of maintaining the golf-links in the grounds of the Istana Negara, indicating details of such cost; (b) what is the nature of responsibility of the Botanic Gardens Department and the City Council Cleansing Department in maintaining these golf-links; and (c) the names of the persons who have played golf there.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed) (for the Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    There are no golf-links as such in the grounds of the Istana Negara. The lawn, gardens and flower-beds of the Istana Negara are maintained by the Botanic Gardens. There are several greens in the grounds and no extra cost is incurred to maintain these.

    The City Council Cleansing Department does the cleansing of the City area, which includes Istana Negara.

    The Prime Minister, with His Excellency's permission, hits practice balls on the playable greens if and when he is free in the evenings.

    Mr Lingam: Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Parliamentary Secretary say by which British Governor were these golf-links made?

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed rose -

    Mr Speaker: Does the Parliamentary Secretary wish to assume responsibility?

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed(In Malay): Because there are no golf-links as such, we cannot go into the matter further.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that it is not only the Prime Minister who plays golf there, but also his British friends?

    Mr Speaker: The question is strictly out of order, being outside ministerial responsibility.

PRIME MINISTER'S PRIVATE
OFFICE AND VISITORS' LOUNGE IN CITY HALL
(Cost of redecoration)


    6. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Prime Minister (a) what is the total cost, with breakdown details (whether under Government or City Council votes), of redecorating the Prime Minister's private office in the City Council since 5th June, 1959, including air-conditioners, panelling, carpets, furniture, curtains, etc.; and (b) what is the total cost, with breakdown details (whether under Government or City Council votes), of redecorating the Prime Minister's Visitors' Lounge for the same period.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    The Prime Minister has no "private office". The cost of making up the two rooms on the second floor of City Hall in September 1959 for the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister was $21,468.70. The Prime Minister's room therefore cost half of this, that is, $10,734.35.

    Authority for this expenditure came from the Fourth Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1959, Head 7, Subhead 15, in Command Paper (N.S.) 18 of 1959.

    The cost of decorating the Prime Minister's Reception cum Conference Room is $8,825.11.

    Authority for this expenditure came from the same Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1959, Head 7, Sub-head 15, in Command Paper (N.S.) 18 of 1959.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: May I ask a supplementary question on question 6?

Column: 622



    Mr Speaker: It is rather unusual for a Parliamentary Secretary to ask a supplementary question.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Will the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister tell the House how this cost compares with the cost of occupying former S.I.T. flats in Upper Pickering Street by the former Minister for National Development where he had a public office and a "secret" room to which even his Parliamentary Secretary and Permanent Secretary had no access?

    Mr Speaker: That supplementary question has no reference whatsoever to the question before the House. Mr Lingam, question No. 7.

"CHANGI COTTAGE" - STATISTICS


    7. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Prime Minister (a) what was the cost and the year of construction of the seaside bungalow at Changi Point known as "Changi Cottage", and what is the estimated value of the land; (b) what is the annual cost of upkeep of this bungalow, giving breakdown details of salaries of caretaker and gardeners, repairs and maintenance, and other expenses; (c) whether the rooms are air-conditioned; (d) what was the cost of redecorating this bungalow in May, 1960; (e) before the redecoration in May 1960, who were entitled to stay there, giving dates; (f) who had stayed in this bungalow since May, 1960, giving dates; and (g) how often have Health and other Government personnel been called in to catch flies and destroy ants at this bungalow and by whom, giving an indication of the cost incurred.

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed (for the Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question:

    (a) The cost of "Changi Cottage" was $24,943.83 and it was constructed in 1950. The estimated value of the land is about $1 a square foot. The cottage is in the

Column: 623

grounds of Changi bungalow, a Government holiday bungalow.

    (b) There is no cost to upkeep this bungalow because the caretaker, the bungalow servant and the gardener of the Changi Holiday Bungalow help to look after "Changi Cottage". The estimated cost for repairs and maintenance is $250 a year. Painting is done once in about four years.

    (c) Two bedrooms are air-conditioned. The air-conditioning was carried out in 1953.

    (d) The cost of painting and repairs to the bungalow in May 1960 was $1,648.96.

    (e) The Yang di-Pertuan Negara and his guests are entitled to occupy the Cottage.

    (f) and (g) There are no records of such domestic details, nor is it part of the Minister's duties to provide such information.

    Mr Lingam: Could the Parliamentary Secretary say which British Governor was responsible for the construction of this seaside bungalow, and was the bungalow used exclusively for that purpose?

    Mr Speaker: The supplementary question is out of order, there being no ministerial responsibility.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that before the redecoration and beautification in May 1960, it was only the Prime Minister who had stayed in that seaside bungalow?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the answer to the question has already indicated that that bungalow is occupied by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara and his guests, and I do not think that it will be in order for the hon. Member to ask any further questions on that point, as

VACANT POSTS IN GOVERNMENT SERVICE HELD
BY OFFICERS IN ACTING CAPACITY


    8. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Finance to state the number of vacant posts in the Government service as at 31st August, 1960, which were held by officers in an acting capacity, and to give a list of such posts.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am unable to supply the hon. Member the information he sought from the data available in my Ministry, but if he so wishes, I will call for returns from all Ministries of Government and compile the figures, which can either be sent directly to the hon. Member or placed before the House at the next sitting. The hon. Member will realise that the total effort involved is quite considerable. If his interest is confined to a particular department or Ministry, I shall be glad if he will inform me accordingly so that an unnecessary burden need not be placed on the administration. I may mention that all acting appointments exceeding the period of two months have to be considered and approved by the Public Service Commission in accordance with section 81 of the Constitution.

3.02 p.m.

    The Chairman: Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before we proceed with the consideration of these Supplementary Estimates?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I so signify.

    The Chairman: The Third Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1960 of the State of Singapore as contained in Paper Cmd. 18 of 1960. The summary is at page 4.

    On Head 34 - Ministry of Labour and Law - there is an amendment standing in the name of the Member for Joo Chiat in relation to the new subhead (Industrial Arbitration Court).

    Mr C. H. Koh (Joo Chiat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 34 be reduced by $10 in respect of the new subhead (Industrial Arbitration Court) therein.

    Mr Speaker. Sir, I speak today in particular reference to the announcement of the Government a few days ago regarding the appointment of the President of the Industrial Arbitration Court. Mr Speaker, Sir, the word "Court", I take it, has been deliberately used in the designation of this Court under the Industrial Relations Ordinance. It was the expectation, I think, in the country that the first President would be a person of some legal experience and qualification. I do not make any personal reference to Dr Gamba except that he does not possess any legal qualification or legal experience. The work of this Industrial Arbitration Court, Mr Speaker, Sir, will draw the attention of a very large number of people of this country. It has been stressed time and time again inside this

Column: 627

House and by both sides of the House that the economic situation of this country is a vital factor in the existence of the people of this country. Mr Speaker, Sir, there has been much attention focussed on the industrial relationship between employers and employees, and we have all been expecting that the Industrial Arbitration Court would be the final answer to the numerous strikes which have plagued this country in the past and, in so plaguing this country, have disturbed the equilibrium of the people whose main concern is the betterment of the economic situation of this country.

    Sir, in the work of the Industrial Arbitration Court, there will no doubt be a great deal of material which does not involve the interpretation of law. Now, such material, Mr Speaker, Sir, would involve a great knowledge of the business of this country. Dr Gamba was the Professor of Economics in the University of Malaya and, as such, we naturally respect his knowledge of economics. But he has no experience of the day-to-day running of big business, and it is my humble submission that a certain amount of knowledge and experience of big business should be an essential qualification of the Judge sitting in the Industrial Arbitration Court. I fail to see how the new appointee can qualify in that respect.

    As to the knowledge of law, Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not need to stress before you that it is no easy matter to interpret the law, and there is a great principle often quoted in the law courts in the administration of law in any country, and that is that justice must not only be done but must seem to be done. Mr Speaker, Sir, the appointment should have gone not only to a person of great legal experience, but should also have gone to a person whose politics cannot be questioned, or, rather, a person who should have no political leanings whatsoever. In the case of this new appointee, there may be some question as to his political leanings. Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, it may perturb employers, particularly when they appear before the Court, which should be absolutely impartial to both employee and employer.

Column: 628



    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not wish to appear to be anticipating the work of this Court, but I hope, when a reply is given to this amendment, that some satisfactory public statement will be made to subdue whatever qualms that may have arisen with the announcement of the appointment.

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Joo Chiat had been present in this House at the time when the Industrial Relations Bill was debated, he would have been able to inform himself of the functions of this Court. On that occasion, Mr Speaker, Sir, I did take pains to inform Members of the House that the Industrial Arbitration Court is not a Court of Judicature. It is a Court that is concerned with the making of collective agreements between employers and unions, its functions are mainly legislative and not judicial. Mr Speaker, Sir, in any dispute where the parties fail to agree, the Minister can, under the provisions of the Ordinance, refer the dispute to the Industrial Arbitration Court. It will be the function of this Court to make the agreement for the parties when they cannot so agree. That is essentially a legislative process and not, strictly speaking, a judicial process. It is for that reason, Mr Speaker, Sir, that it is considered unnecessary that the holder of this appointment should hold accepted legal qualifications.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is provision for the appointment of a Registrar under the Ordinance. It is our intention to ensure that the person who fills that appointment will hold recognised legal qualifications so that he could assist the President whenever points of legal difficulty arise. There is also provision under the Ordinance for the State Advocate-General to be consulted by the Court when points of legal difficulty arise; and when he intervenes, members of the Bar have the right to appear before the Court. There are two sections of the Ordinance which provide that members of the Bar no longer have a right, once this Ordinance has been brought into force, to take part in the process of

Column: 629

collective bargaining and members of the Bar also have no right to appear before this Court. I have pointed all that out before.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on the question of the political leanings of Dr Charles Gamba who has been named, I can assure the Member for Joo Chiat that he is not a member of the People's Action Party. He is a person who has played a great part in labour economics in this country. He has appeared on various tribunals dealing with labour problems.
